thread.title_full: Around college football | Notre Dame players get used to reality TV spotlight | Buckeye Xtra Sports

title: Around college football | Notre Dame players get used to reality TV spotlight | Buckeye Xtra Sports
text:
>> Get the most out of your Ohio State experience, follow @BuckeyeXtra on Twitter 
Running back C.J. Prosise and receiver Chris Brown were locked in an intense game of video soccer. Just then, the Showtime camera crew following Notre Dame players this season started talking to Prosise. He wasn’t happy.
“Of course, while I’m answering questions, Chris scores,” Prosise said. “So I’m like, ‘Dude, I can’t talk anymore.’ ”
Too late: Brown won 1-0 and taunted his roommate.
The headaches have become part of the deal for players-turned-reality-stars for the cable series A Season with Notre Dame . The show is similar to HBO’s Hard Knocks , which follows an NFL team through training camp.
>> Follow Rob Oller on Twitter during the games, become a part of  Scarlet & Gray Matter  in  The Dispatch 
Fighting Irish players have had to adjust to a crew of about a dozen following them daily. That number grows to more than 50 on game days. The 11th-ranked Irish (6-1) say it was awkward at first.
Even for coach Brian Kelly, who said he has been in the bathroom when he has realized he’s still miked.
Still, they are enjoying the attention.
“At times it can be a little much, a little bit of a hassle,” Prosise said. “But it’s kind of cool to say you have your own TV show.”
Viewers have seen some lows, including the raw emotion of quarterback Malik Zaire after he suffered a broken ankle to end his season.
They saw the stress of players studying for midterms while preparing for rival Southern California.
>> Click for details on how to win tickets and trips to OSU games from Dispatch Reader Rewards 
But they also saw the team being rewarded with a meal of porterhouse steaks and crab legs after beating Navy.
“I like crab legs,” linebacker Joe Schmidt says. “It tastes like victory.”
THURSDAY’S HIGHLIGHT No. 22 Temple 24, East Carolina 14: P.J. Walker threw a late 23-yard touchdown pass to Robby Anderson and Temple (7-0, 4-0) rallied to beat host East Carolina (4-4, 2-2) in an American Athletic Conference game.
Walker finished 19 of 35 for 250 yards for the Owls, who are off to the best start in school history.
